japanese:
（なんだ？
　２人してキョロキョロして……）
translation:
(What's going on?
 Both of them are looking around nervously...)

japanese: よう、どうかしたのか？
translation: Yo, is something wrong?

japanese: ああ、上杉君。
translation: Oh, it's Uesugi-kun.

japanese: ……おどかさないでください。
translation: Don't scare me like that.

japanese:
声をかけただけだぞ……。
なにかあったのか？
translation:
I just called out to you...
Did something happen?

japanese:
あの、ちょうど郷土村を
見て回ってきたところですが――
translation:
Well, we were just looking around
the Native Okinawan Village when%p-2;――

japanese:
そこで解説員の方から、
沖縄にはキジムナーという妖怪がいると
聞いてしまいまして。
translation:
Someone from the tour guide staff told us that 
there's a yokai monster called 'Kijimuna' in Okinawa.

japanese:
（は？　もしかして妖怪を怖がってるのか？
　確かに五月は怖がりだったが……）
translation:
(Huh? Are they scared of yokai?
 Itsuki, for sure, is easily frightened, but...)

japanese:
もしかしたら、この近くにも
キジムナーがいるかもしれないと思うと……。
translation:
I can't help but think that there might be
a Kijimuna around here too...

japanese: おいおい、さすがに怖がりすぎだろ。
translation: Hey-hey, there's nothing to be this scared of.

japanese: で、でも！　良い妖怪みたいでしたよね！？
translation: B-but Kijimuna seemed like a good yokai, didn't it?

japanese: 妖怪に良い奴なんているのか？
translation: Are there really nice yokai out there?

japanese:
ええ、キジムナーは人間と仲良しなんです！
しかも魚を捕るのが得意で、
一緒に漁へ行けば必ず大漁になったとか！
translation:
Yes, Kijimuna is actually friendly with humans!
It's good at catching fish, so if you
go fishing together, you'll always catch a lot!

japanese:
ですので、キジムナーと友達になれたら
大抵の場合、お金持ちになれたらしいです！
translation:
So, if you can become friends with Kijimuna,
you'll usually become rich!

japanese:
へー、マジで良い奴じゃないか。
なんなら、お知り合いになりたいくらいじゃないか？
translation:
Wow, it really does seem like a good yokai.
I'd sure like to get to know it, wouldn't you?

japanese: いえ、この話にはまだ続きがあるのです。
translation: Well, there's still more to this story.

japanese: 続き？
translation: More?

japanese: 一見、良い妖怪に思えるキジムナーなのですが――
translation:
Although Kijimuna seems like a good yokai
at first glance%p-2;――

japanese:
自分を騙したり裏切ったりした相手に対しては、
徹底的に祟り、恐ろしい報復をするそうなんです。
translation:
It's said that if someone deceives or betrays Kijimuna,
it will curse them completely
and exact a terrible revenge.

japanese: お、思い出させないでくださいぃ！
translation: P-please don't remind me of that!

japanese: なんだよ、その恐ろしい報復って。
translation: What kind of terrible revenge are we talking about?

japanese: 口に出すのも恐ろしいものですよ……。
translation: It's scary just to say it out loud...

japanese:
まあ、妖怪あるある話だな！
そういうことをしなければいいだけだ！
translation:
Well, that's just a typical yokai story!
Just don't do anything to provoke it,
and you'll be fine!

japanese:
ですが、人間と妖怪とでは
価値観が異なっているのではないでしょうか？
translation:
But isn't it possible that humans and yokai
have different values and perspectives?

japanese:
もし、知らぬ間に
キジムナーを怒らせてしまっていたら……！
translation:
What if we've unwittingly
angered Kijimuna without realizing it...!

japanese:
妖怪なんて作り話だ。
フィクションにそこまでマジになるなよ。
translation:
Yokai are just made up stories.
Don't take fiction so seriously.

japanese: ……そういう問題ではないのですが？
translation: ...That's not the problem though, is it?

japanese:
どうやら、私たちと上杉君の価値観も
違っていたようですね。
translation:
It seems that our values
and those of Uesugi-kun also differ.

japanese:
人間同士でも価値観が違うことはありますし、
ますますわかり合うのは難しそうです。
translation:
Even among humans, we can have different 
values that make it seem more difficult to 
understand one another.

japanese:
私たちのような五つ子でも、
上手くいかないことも多くありますからね。
translation:
Even for us quintuplets,
there are many things that don't work out.

japanese: ……ですね。
translation: ...That's right.

japanese: 触らぬ神に祟りなし、だな。
translation: It's the gods you don't want to anger.

japanese:
もし妖怪を見かけても、
見なかったことにしちまうのが
お互いのためだったりすることもあるだろ。
translation:
If you ever see an actual yokai, 
maybe pretending you didn't 
would be best for both your sakes.

japanese: ……それが一番なのかもしれませんね。
translation: ...That might be the best course of action.

japanese:
でも、出会ってしまったら
もう引き返せないかもしれませんよ？
translation:
But if you do actually meet one,
there might be no turning back, you know?

japanese:
人間同士でも価値観が違うことはありますし、
ますますわかり合うのは難しそうです。
translation:
Even among humans, we can have different 
values that make it seem more difficult to 
understand one another.

japanese:
私たちのような五つ子でも、
上手くいかないことも多くありますからね。
translation:
Even for us quintuplets,
there are many things that don't work out.

japanese: ……ですね。
translation: ...That's right.

japanese: 価値観が違うって、なんでわかるんだ？
translation:
And how do you know that humans and yokai
have different values?

japanese:
えっ？
それは……。
translation:
Huh?
Well...

japanese:
人間に近い所で生活している妖怪なら、
人間側の事情も知ってそうなもんだが。
translation:
If it's a yokai that lives close to humans,
it's likely that they would already know about
the human way of life, as well.

japanese:
いや、根本的な世界観が違うのか？
そうなると、同じ物に対してでも
双方の抱く価値観が違うってのはありえるのか……。
translation:
Or, is it a fundamental difference in worldview?
If that's the case, it's possible for both parties
to have different values for the same object, isn't it.

japanese: いえ、そこまで深く考えずとも。
translation: Well, you don't have to think about it that deeply.

japanese:
ふふっ！
でも、上杉君らしいです。
translation: Fufu! But that's so Uesugi-kun.

japanese:
人間同士でも価値観が違うことはありますし、
ますますわかり合うのは難しそうです。
translation:
Even among humans, we can have different 
values that make it seem more difficult to 
understand one another.

japanese:
私たちのような五つ子でも、
上手くいかないことも多くありますからね。
translation:
Even for us quintuplets,
there are many things that don't work out.

japanese: ……ですね。
translation: ...That's right.

japanese:
（こうして見ているとそっくりな２人だが、
　確かに違う人間なんだよな）
translation:
(They look so alike when you look at them 
 like this but they are definitely different people.)

japanese: （違うからこそ、それを見極めて欲しい）
translation:
(It's precisely these differences 
 that they want me to figure out.)

japanese:
（そういう意味も込めて、
　今回の試練を課してきたのかもしれない……）
translation:
(With that meaning in mind, maybe 
 that's why they gave me this trial...)
